December 2018 
 
 
Mongolia: Improving Health Care Financing for 
Universal Health Coverage

Policy.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the development of a 
more efficient public health financing system in Mongolia by creating an effective health services 
purchasing model, including policy reforms and institutional development.1 This is to shift state 
funding from financing budget lines (input-based) to purchasing services (output-based), to allow 
for a more equitable health care system. The TA will lay the foundation for strategic purchasing 
in the health sector,2 which will be implemented under a proposed multitranche financing facility 
for Improving  Access to  Health  Services  for Disadvantaged  Groups.3 The TA  will  support 
Mongolia in promoting a more equitable health care system and universal health coverage 
(Sustainable Development Goal 3). 
 
2.  The TA4 is included in the country operations business plan, 2019–2021 of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for Mongolia.5 It is in line with ADB’s country partnership strategy for 
Mongolia, 2017–2020 and Operational Plan for Health, 2015–2020.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Despite  successful  health  reforms  since  2005,  Mongolia  continues  to  experience 
inadequate and inequitable access to quality health services, especially among disadvantaged 
groups, and high out-of-pocket expenses (OPEs). Total public expenditure on health is 3.4% of 
gross domestic product, which is below the World Health Organization’s target of 5.0%. State 
budget funding has increased nominally for the last 10 years, but government health spending as 
a proportion of total public spending and as a proportion of gross domestic product has dropped. 
Mongolia needs to increase public financing on health and improve its effective use. Hospitals 
have three revenue sources: state funding (70%); health insurance funds (about 20%); and other 
sources, mainly OPEs paid directly by patients (10%). The effective management and use of 
these funds are greatly needed to transform the health care financing system into an output-based 
system with stronger financial protection for the poor. 
 
                                                
1  Purchasing refers to the allocation of pooled funds to providers that deliver health care goods and services to the 
covered population, as per the defined benefit package. 
2  With strategic purchasing, purchasers in the health sector, usually government or public purchasers, define what 
health services will be provided, the cost of providing these services, how these services will be delivered, and who 
will deliver them. Strategic purchasing (i) aims to use payment levels and methods to move toward universal health 
coverage, (ii) involves an overall resource allocation discussion, and (iii) moves away from the individual bilateral 
relationship between one purchaser and a single provider. Most developing member countries, including Mongolia, 
use passive ways to purchase health services, such as direct out-of-pocket payments by patients, government 
budgetary allocation based on historical trends with no link to what is being provided, and health insurance benefits 
and payment methods that do not demand contracted providers to support universal health coverage goals. 
Countries that demonstrate effective strategic purchasing in the health sector include Germany, Italy, Japan, the 
Netherlands, and the United Kingdom. These countries have developed well-established governance arrangements, 
benefit packages with market-based fee schedules and medicine costs, payment systems, and information 
management and reporting systems. 
3  The proposed multitranche financing facility is included in the latest country operations business plan of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for Mongolia (ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2019–2021. 
Manila). ADB Board approval is scheduled in the first quarter of 2019. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 2 October 2018. 
5  ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2019–2021. Manila. The TA title was adjusted to better 
reflect the scope of the TA. 
6  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020—Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of 
Economic Difficulty. Manila; and ADB. 2015. Health in Asia and the Pacific: A Focused Approach to Address the 
Health Needs of ADB Developing Member Countries—Operational Plan for Health, 2015–2020. Manila.

2 
4.  State funding challenges. The Integrated Budget Law, 2013 mandates a unified budget 
approved by Parliament. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) manages a single account consisting of 
state and local government funding and health insurance funds. State funding in its current setup 
is inefficient. Its budgeting, allocation, and control are entirely budget line item-based, leading to 
complete passive financing of health services. This is mostly based on historical budgets that are 
poorly linked to actual cost, the volume of services, and inefficient resource allocation. As a result, 
hospitals have no incentive to be efficient or to provide quality health services. Changing the 
current provider payment method from budget line (input-based) to purchasing services (output-
based) will increase the efficiency of care and the quality of services.7 
 
5.  Lack of coherence between Ministry of Health (MOH) policies and the MOF’s budgeting 
and fund allocation reinforces the passive nature of services purchased with state funds. The 
current setup does not incentivize health providers to deliver more rational care (e.g., penalizing 
the excess use of antibiotics by withholding payments). The performance assessment system for 
budget managers and providers that was established more than a decade ago is not effective, 
i.e., results of the assessments have no real effect on resource allocation. 
 
6.  Health insurance funds challenges. The Health Insurance Organization (HIO) under the 
MOH is responsible for managing health insurance funds by contracting public and private service 
providers.8 The HIO has been granted some degree of autonomy, but its operations are strictly 
within the unified budget framework.  Thus, HIO is not able to act as an active purchaser to ensure 
efficient resource allocation. For instance, the control of expenses is based on line items and 
historical trends that lack flexibility in allocating funds to priority areas. 
 
7.  The HIO’s institutional capacity has improved since 2013 with ADB support.9 The key 
operational system of purchasing functions requires further improvement, however, and HIO staff 
capacity for fund management, contracting, contract management, and quality monitoring needs 
strengthening. 
 
8.  Out-of-pocket expense challenges. OPEs in Mongolia’s health sector are very high 
because of weak purchasing practices, unnecessary admissions, overprescription of drugs, 
unregulated setting of schedule fees leading to abuse, health insurance-imposed ceilings on 
reimbursement of diagnostic tests, and gaps in benefit packages. Overall, high OPEs and 
inefficient resource allocations in the sector have resulted in limited financial protection for 
Mongolians against ill health. In 2014, 0.41% of households fell below the national poverty line 
because of health payments. If these high OPEs continue, the number of poor households is 
expected to increase.10 
 
9.  The government has committed to decreasing the share of OPEs and state funding, and 
increasing the expenses to be covered by health insurance funds managed by the HIO. To 
improve the efficiency and effectiveness of public health financing and accelerate the attainment 
                                                
7  World Health Organization. Moving from Passive to Strategic Purchasing. 
  http://www.who.int/health_financing/topics/purchasing/passive-to-strategic-purchasing/en/. 
8  The HIO has been an agency under the jurisdiction of the MOH since 2017. 
9  ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance to Mongolia for Strengthening the Health Insurance System. Manila. The TA, 
financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, helped the HIO improve basic management functions and health 
services purchasing capacity to cover about 20% of hospital revenues. This knowledge and support TA will continue 
the regulatory, institutional, and human resources development of the HIO to actively purchase services for an 
additional 70%—the share of hospital revenues that currently comes from budget line items by the state funds. 
10 World Health Organization; and Government of Mongolia, MOH. 2017. Household Catastrophic and Impoverishing 
Health Payments in Mongolia. Ulaanbaatar.

3 
of universal health coverage, the TA will support Mongolia in developing and initiating the 
implementation of a strategic purchasing model in the health sector. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: health status of Mongolians improved.11 The 
TA will have the following outcome: strategic purchaser model approved and initiated.12 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: Strategic purchasing model defined. The TA will (i) assess the current 
funding of hospitals, the regulatory framework, and the purchasing practices in the health sector; 
(ii) design an integrated purchasing system; and (iii) develop a road map and a required regulatory 
framework for the introduction and implementation of the strategic purchaser in Mongolia’s health 
sector. 
 
12.  Output 2: Government and health care provider capacity and capability for strategic 
purchasing implementation strengthened. The TA will facilitate the implementation of the 
strategic  purchaser.  It  will  (i)  create  awareness  through  information,  education,  and 
communication activities related to strategic purchasing to address potential resistance in the 
government and the health sector; (ii) carry out a training needs assessment and program for 
government entities involved in health services purchasing, i.e., the MOF, the MOH, selected local 
governments, and the National Health Insurance Council,13 to (a) enhance stewardship, planning 
and policy prioritization, and coordination for strategic purchasing; and (b) improve governance 
to oversee health insurance operations in coordination with the MOH; and (iii) train health 
providers in the public and private sectors to enhance their knowledge and capacity for negotiation 
with the strategic purchaser. 
 
13.  Output 3: Institutionalization of the strategic purchaser initiated. The TA will (i) map 
health  services  and  define  corresponding  benefit  packages,  their  costs,  and  purchasing 
mechanisms  for  services  previously  funded  by  the  state  funds  through  budget  line  items;  
(ii)  develop  a  performance-based  reporting  system  using  information  and  communication 
technology to inform the MOF of the results of purchased health services using state funding; and 
(iii) strengthen the purchasing functions of the HIO, i.e., fund management, contracting, contract 
management, costing, and quality monitoring. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,150,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
15.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, a meeting room for the project implementation unit and consultants, and other 
in-kind contributions. 
                                                
11 Government of Mongolia. 2017. State Policy on Health. Resolution No. 24 of 2017. Ulaanbaatar. 
12 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
13 The National Health Insurance Council is a subgroup in Parliament consisting of nine parliamentarians.

4 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA, which will be implemented from December 2018 to November 
2020. Working closely with ADB’s Mongolia Resident Mission, the Urban and Social Sectors 
Division of ADB’s East Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; and 
provide staff to act as resource persons in the workshops. The MOF will be the executing agency, 
and the MOH will be the implementing agency.  
 
17.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

Source: ADB estimates. 
 
18.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.14 ADB will recruit a consulting firm through quality- and cost-based selection 
method using a quality–cost ratio of 90:10. The selected firm will provide 57 person-months of 
consulting services in developing and initiating a strategic purchaser model in Mongolia’s health 
sector. ADB will also engage, as individual consultants, a national project coordinator for 20 
person-months and a national administrative and finance officer for 20 person-months. The 
national consultants will support the executing and implementing agencies on day-to-day activities 
for smooth TA implementation. 
 
                                                
14 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$1,000,000 to the Government of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction for Improving Health Care Financing for Universal Health Coverage, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Strategic purchasing model defined 
1.1 Assess the current funding of hospitals, the regulatory framework, and the purchasing practices in the 
health sector by Q3 2019 
1.2 Design an integrated purchasing system by Q4 2019 
1.3 Develop a road map and a required regulatory framework for the strategic purchaser by Q1 2020 
2.  Government and health care provider capacity and capability for strategic purchasing 
implementation strengthened 
2.1 Create awareness through information, education, and communication activities related to strategic 
purchasing to address potential resistance in the government and the health sector by Q1 2020 
2.2 Carry out a training needs assessment and program for government entities involved in health 
services purchasing (the HIO, the MOF, the MOH, the NHIC, and selected local governments) to 
enhance stewardship, planning and policy prioritization, and coordination for strategic purchasing; and 
improve governance to oversee health insurance operations in coordination with the MOH by Q1 2020 
2.3 Conduct a study tour to Japan for the selected participants to learn health care financing and strategic 
purchaser practices in Japan’s health sector, specifically (i) the procedure for setting the fee schedule 
that controls the total cost of the system and limits out-of-pocket expenses (controlling extra billing); 
and (ii) the negotiation procedure and practice on the fee schedule by Q2 2020. 
2.4 Train health providers in the public and private sectors to enhance their knowledge and capacity for 
negotiation with the strategic purchaser by Q4 2020 
3.  Institutionalization of the strategic purchaser initiated 
3.1 Define health services, corresponding benefit packages, their costs, and payment mechanisms for 
services previously funded by the state through budget line items by Q2 2020 
3.2 Develop a performance-based reporting system to inform the MOF of the results of purchased health 
services using state funding by Q3 2020 
3.3 Strengthen the purchasing functions of the HIO (fund management, contracting, contract 
management, costing, and quality monitoring) by Q4 2020 
Inputs 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction: $1,000,000 
Note: The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, a meeting room for the project implementation unit and consultants, and other 
in-kind contributions.

Not Applicable
